data.text: Contents
Introduction

There is a wide variation in reported incidence of shoulder dystocia. Studies between 1986 & 2016 reported incidences ranging from 0.1% to 3.0 % of all births. It is unclear why the rates are different, but better awareness may increase reported rates.

In terms of prevention, shoulder dystocia is a largely unpredictable and unpreventable event. No studies have found a single risk factor or combinations that are reliable predictors. If antenatal risk factors are identified this should be discussed with the mother and obstetrician and recorded in the case notes. Anticipation can then aid forward planning of care. Conventional risk factors predicted 16% of cases of shoulder dystocia that resulted in infant morbidity and therefore Shoulder dystocia is not usually clinically predictable, Staff should be prepared for its occurrence at any vaginal birth.
Risk factors pre-labour include previous shoulder dystocia, macrosomia, gestational age, maternal diabetes mellitus, maternal obesity.
Intrapartum risk factors include prolonged first stage of labour, prolonged second stage of labour, labour augmentation and operative vaginal birth

Recognition of shoulder dystocia: There may be difficulty with birth of the face or chin. When the head is born, it remains tightly to the vulva. The chin retracts and depresses the perineum (Turtle neck sign) or the anterior shoulder fails to release with maternal effort and/or when routine axial traction is applied.

Evidence based algorithms for the management of shoulder dystocia recommend resolution maneuvers designed to improve the relative dimensions of the maternal pelvis (McRoberts' position and all fours' position), Suprapubic pressure, delivery of posterior arm to reduce the diameter of the fetal shoulders and / or move the fetal shoulders into a wider pelvis diameter (suprapubic pressure, internal rotational maneuvers.
Scope
The purpose of this guideline is to enable the practitioner to anticipate, recognize and manage this serious obstetric emergency.
Background

Shoulder dystocia can occur when there is an impaction of the fetal anterior shoulder against the maternal symphysis pubis after the fetal head has been delivered and when the breadth of the shoulders exceeds the diameter of the pelvic inlet preventing immediate delivery of the baby (ALSO 2000) (Advanced Life Support in Obstetrics).
Definitions:

Shoulder dystocia is defined as a vaginal cephalic delivery that requires additional obstetric maneuvers to deliver the fetus after the head has delivered and gentle traction has failed. . Shoulder dystocia occurs when either the anterior, or less commonly the posterior, fetal shoulder impacts on the maternal symphysis, or sacral promontory, respectively. An objective diagnosis of a prolongation of head-to-body delivery time of more than  seconds has also been proposed.

table_items.text: Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists

data.text: Roles and responsibilities

The Specialist Nurse for Guidelines and Audit is responsible for ensuring  clinical policies, guidelines and SOPs, are evidence-based and developed in line with national guidelines and following appropriate consultation.
The clinical director is responsible for the implementation of this guideline within the directorate.
The Head of Midwifery, maternity matrons and maternity managers are responsible for ensuring maternity staff are aware of the guideline and implement it.
The Obstetric Clinical Lead Consultant and Labour Ward Lead Consultant are responsible for ensuring the implementation of this guideline within the clinical setting.
All maternity staff are responsible for ensuring they are familiar with this guideline in relation to their practice and have the appropriate skills to implement this guideline.
Procedure: Shoulder Dystocia is an obstetrics emergency
Prompt recognition is the key to appropriate management:
Difficulty in delivery of the face or chin.
Head remains tightly applied to the vulva or even retracting( turtle neck)
Failure of restitution of the head
Failure of the shoulders to descend with maternal effort or when routine axial traction is applied.

Help should be summoned immediately. In a hospital setting, this should include further midwifery assistance, including Labour Ward Co-ordinator, experienced obstetrician, a neonatal resuscitation team and an anaesthetist. In the community call for a Paramedic ambulance.

Current international guidance recommends four basic shoulder dystocia resolution maneuvers: McRoberts position/ all fours position, suprapubic pressure, delivery of the posterior arm, and internal rotations. The individual situation will determine the order of actions taken. (Refer to Appendix A and B for PROMPT algorithm and Management of Shoulder and Dystocia)

McRoberts' (Refer to Appendix A for illustration) manoeuvre is one of the less invasive manoeuvers and should be undertaken first. Lie the mother flat. With one assistant on either side – hyper flex the mothers legs against her abdomen so her knees are up towards her ears. If the legs are in the lithotomy position, her legs will need to be removed from the supports to achieve the positioning. The maternal buttocks are lifted off the bed during the hyperflexion of the hips, therefore rotating the pelvis. Routine axial traction then applied to ascertain if the dystocia has been resolved.

All fours position is positioning the woman in a flexed all-fours position with thighs against the abdomen, having a similar effect to the McRoberts' (essentially McRoberts position upside down). For a slim, mobile woman without epidural anaesthesia and with a single midwifery attendant, the ‘all-fours' position is probably more appropriate, and clearly this may be a useful option in a community setting. The woman should be asked to roll over so that she is supporting herself on her upper arms and knees, with hips and knees flexed. Routine axial traction then applied to ascertain if the dystocia has been resolved.

Suprapubic pressure should be applied from the side of the fetal back, which will reduce the diameter of the fetal shoulders. Pressure should be applied just above the symphysis pubis in a downward and lateral direction. With suprapubic pressure, there is no evidence that rocking is not more effective than continuous pressure, nor that it should be performed for 30 seconds for it to be effective. The emphasis needs to be on applying routine gentle axial traction to see if the manoeuvre has been successful and if the anterior shoulder is not released, then an alternative manoeuvre should be attempted.

Evaluation for episiotomy is to be assessed at the appropriate time, just before doing the internal manoeuvres rather than at the beginning of the scenario. Episiotomy may not always be required; Episiotomy will not relieve the obstruction but may give additional space for internal manoeuvres.
If McRoberts / all fours position and / or suprapubic pressure are not effective then there are two internal manoeuvres: delivery of the posterior arm or internal rotation.

All internal manoeuvres should commence the same way with the insertion of the whole hand into the sacral hollow. Once in the sacral hollow you can assess if the posterior arm is easily accessible and remove it if it is. If not commence internal rotational manoeuvres.
Gentle axial traction in line with the axis of the fetal spine should be performed rather than gentle downward traction.

In all cases of shoulder dystocia, the midwife responsible for the care of the patient should ensure that the shoulder dystocia Proforma is completed. The original copy should be retained in the health care records. The responsible midwife should report the incident via Datixweb system. (Refer to Appendix C for the Shoulder Dystocia Proforma)
Complications
In the event the manoeuvres fail the obstetric registrar may need to perform:
Symphysiotomy - division of the symphysis pubis
Zavanelli manoeuvre, procedure to LSCS - the head is flexed and reinserted into the vagina
Deliberate clavicle fracture / destructive surgery - if the baby has died; use with caution as a last resort with consultant obstetrician in attendance.
These maneuvers are only to be performed by staff who have had specific training to carry out these procedures. In these circumstances the consultant on call must be contacted to attend.
Maternal complications of shoulder dystocia:
Third and fourth degree tears
Post-partum Haemorrhage
(Refer to ‘Guideline for the management of postpartum haemorrhage', register number   04234)
Psychological distress
Uterine rupture
Symphyseal separation
Neonatal complications of shoulder dystocia:
Stillbirth
Brachial plexus injury
Fractures
Acidosis; the pH drops by 0.04 per minute
Hypoxia
Immediate postpartum management
Ensure careful observations are carried out on the baby, due to the risk of trauma and possible neurological damage. (Refer to ‘Guideline for resuscitation of the newborn, register number 07074)

Clear accurate documentation of the sequence of manoeuvres, timings and personnel present to be recorded in the hospital maternity notes. Contemporaneous record keeping is essential (refer to the guideline for maternity record keeping including documentation in handheld records, register number 06036).
The Shoulder Dystocia Proforma should be completed. (Refer to Appendix B)
Cord blood samples must be taken to ascertain arterial and venous levels and the result must be stapled to the neonatal page of the Labour care and Baby delivery record.
The paediatric team should be informed and immediately review any suspected injury following shoulder dystocia. Early intervention is an important aspect of a good outcome.
Debriefing should ensue for the patient, her family and all staff involved.
The responsible midwife should report the incident via Datixweb system.
Brachial plexus injury

The brachial Plexus is vulnerable to trauma owing to its large size, superficial location and position between the neck and arm. Between 8 & 12% of BPI are reported to be permanent. Injuries can be divided into upper (Erbs Palsy), Lower (Klumpkes palsy) and total Brachial plexus Injury.
The risk factors are as follows:
Macrosomia
Prolonged labour
Shoulder dystocia
Breech delivery
A history, physical examination and the following investigations may identify and diagnose Brachial plexus:
Posture of the arm. Movements of fingers, wrist, elbow, shoulder. Neck swelling or haematoma
Bruising or swelling of the arm
Referral process

If a midwife or paediatric senior house officer has identified any of the above findings then a referral should be made to the Advanced Neonatal Nurse Practitioner (ANNP) or Paediatric Registrar to conduct a further examination of the baby to investigate the following:
Clavicular, humeral fractures (X-Ray may be required).
Horner's syndrome
If there is perinatal hypoxia, observe for convulsions and check cord gas.
Look for dislocation of the shoulder, confirm by ultrasound scan of the shoulder
Clear documentation of resuscitation and examination
Chest X ray for phrenic nerve palsy

If a brachial plexus injury has been identified the Advanced Neonatal Nurse Practitioner (ANNP) or Paediatric Registrar should inform his/her consultant and maintain clear and accurate documentation throughout in the health care records. (Refer to Appendix C)
The management of brachial plexus injury should involve the explanation to parents of the physical findings and diagnosis. All discussions and care should be documented in the health care records.
Questions regarding the delivery should be discussed with the obstetrician or midwife.
A referral should be made by the paediatric registrar to the Physiotherapy Department at Moulsham Grange, Chelmsford for all babies with a brachial plexus injury.
A follow-up out-patient appointment should be arranged for four weeks at Broomfield Hospital, Chelmsford on discharge home.

If the infant continues to show no significant improvements by four weeks a further specialist referral is needed. The infant needs to be seen in the Royal National Orthopaedic Hospital, London before 3 months of age.
Training requirements
All midwifery and obstetric staff must attend yearly mandatory training which includes skills and drills training, involving the management of shoulder dystocia.
(Refer to ‘Mandatory training policy for Maternity Services (incorporating training needs
Analysis. Register number 09062 and PROMPT (PRactical Obstetric Multi-Professional
Training))
All midwifery and obstetric staff are to ensure that their knowledge and skills are up-to-date in order to complete their portfolio for appraisal.
Guideline Management

11.3.1 As an integral part of the knowledge, skills framework, staff are appraised annually to ensure competency in computer skills and the ability to access the current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site.
Infection prevention
All staff should follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention by ensuring that they effectively ‘decontaminate their hands' before and after each procedure.

All staff should ensure that they follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention, using Aseptic Non-Touch Technique (ANTT) when carrying out procedures i.e. vaginal examinations and conducting deliveries.
Audit and monitoring

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring

Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Identification and Management of Shoulder Dystocia
Cases identified by DATIX , notes Audit
Every identified case of shoulder dystocia

data.text: Audit of shoulder dystocia cases should be undertaken by the Specialist Midwife for Risk Management. Findings from individual cases will be reported at the Maternity Risk Management Group (MRMG) and progress with any identified actions will be monitored at subsequent meetings

Audit of compliance with this guideline will be considered on an annual audit basis in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy and Policy (register number 08076), the Corporate Clinical Audit and Quality Improvement Project Plan and the Maternity annual audit work plan; to encompass national and local audit and clinical governance identifying key harm themes. The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group will identify a lead for the audit.
As a minimum the following specific requirements will be monitored:
Identification of factors associated with shoulder dystocia
Systematic emergency management of shoulder dystocia
Standards for record-keeping in relation to shoulder dystocia
Process for using a reporting form which contains the RCOG minimum data set
Process for the follow up of the newborn where there is actual/suspected brachial plexus injury or any other injury associated with the complications of the delivery
Maternity service's expectations for staff training, as identified in the training needs analysis

A review of a suitable sample of health records of patients to include the minimum requirements as highlighted in point 12.3 will be audited. A minimum compliance 75% is required for each requirement. Where concerns are identified more frequent audit will be undertaken.

The findings of the audit will be reported to and approved by the Multi-disciplinary Risk Management Group (MRMG) and an action plan with named leads and timescales will be developed to address any identified deficiencies. Performance against the action plan will be monitored by this group at subsequent meetings.
The audit report will be reported to the monthly Directorate Governance Meeting (DGM) and significant concerns relating to compliance will be entered on the local Risk Assurance Framework.
Key findings and learning points from the audit will be submitted to the Patient Safety Group within the integrated learning report.
Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved locally by the Maternity and Gynaecology Practice Steering Group prior to submission to the Controlled Document team for ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.

It is the Guidelines and Audit Nurse's and author's responsibility to inform the Maternity and Gynaecology Practice Steering Group and appropriate Maternity Services' staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix D)
References
